946893925310017537.text:
My IDEAL filesystem for sharing would:

1) Work on Linux, BSD, macOS and Windows out of the box
2) Not worry about cross-computer permissions by default

FAT32 almost fits the bill, but it has a crummy 4GB limit on file size. ZFS works well, but is too fiddly for the average user

946892581278908417.text:
# Fuck it.
sudo chown -R root:root .
sudo chmod -R uog+rw,uog+X .

946892102469746688.text: I'm also ruthlessly butchering the permissions, because UNIX permissions make no sense when you move between computers due to user ID mismatches. My solution is everything owned by root:root, files readable and writable by EVERYONE, and directories executable...

946890594256748545.text: It still astounds me how annoying it is to share an external hard drive between multiple OSes. Because of Microsoft and Apple's refusal to do anything sensible (open-source their filesystems), I am now using #ZFS as common ground between #Linux and #macOS...
